1960.Milestones: Continuation of 'The Great Migration' to the US seeking economic opportunities; peak of Operation Bootstrap industrialization efforts.

1961.Milestones: Net emigration persists, although lower than the previous year.

1962.Milestones: Sustained emigration towards the United States.

1963.Milestones: The trend of high emigration continues.

1964.Milestones: Emigration remains a key demographic factor.

1965.Milestones: One of the net emigration peaks during this decade.

1966.Milestones: Slight decrease in net emigration compared to the previous year.

1967.Milestones: First plebiscite on political status held (Commonwealth status wins).

1968.Milestones: Luis A. Ferré (PNP) wins the governorship, the first elected governor not belonging to the PPD.

1970.Milestones: Notable reduction in net emigration compared to the previous decade. Beginning of a migration slowdown.

1972.Milestones: Net emigration reaches one of its lowest points to date.

1973.Milestones: Global oil crisis impacts the global and local economy, affecting incentives to migrate.

1974.Milestones: Low net emigration continues amidst global economic uncertainty.

1975.Milestones: The lowest level of net emigration recorded in the dataset so far.

1976.Milestones: A slight rebound in net emigration begins.

1977.Milestones: Section 936 of the US Internal Revenue Code is approved, consolidating tax incentives for manufacturing.

1978.Milestones: The economy shows dependence on Section 936 incentives.

1979.Milestones: First year with positive net migration recorded in this dataset, potentially indicating return migration or reduced departures.

1980.Milestones: Beginning of a new phase of negative net emigration. Economic recession in the US.

1981.Milestones: Net emigration increases amid economic difficulties.

1984.Milestones: Slight moderation in the net outflow.

1985.Milestones: Uptick in emigration. Mameyes landslide disaster in Ponce.

1986.Milestones: Net emigration exceeds 10,000 for the first time since the 1960s in this dataset.

1989.Milestones: Hurricane Hugo causes significant damage, potentially boosting emigration.

1990.Milestones: Net emigration decreases compared to the late 80s.

1993.Milestones: Status plebiscite (Commonwealth wins). Slight increase in net emigration.

1994.Milestones: The phase-out of Section 936 is announced, generating future economic uncertainty.

1996.Milestones: The 10-year phase-out of Section 936 formally begins.

1997.Milestones: Net emigration increases as the end of Section 936 incentives approaches.

1998.Milestones: Hurricane Georges hits the island causing devastation. Status plebiscite ('None of the above' option wins).

1999.Milestones: Protests against the US military presence in Vieques intensify after an accidental death.

2000.Milestones: Sharp increase in net emigration, coinciding with the start of a new decade and persistent economic uncertainty.

2001.Milestones: High emigration continues. Post-9/11 economic impact in the US could affect the situation.

2002.Milestones: The trend of high emigration is maintained.

2003.Milestones: Definitive closure of the Roosevelt Roads Naval Station and end of military practices in Vieques.

2004.Milestones: Net emigration remains at very high levels.

2005.Milestones: Last full year with residual benefits of Section 936.

2006.Milestones: Definitive end of Section 936. Official start of the economic recession in Puerto Rico that would last over a decade.

2007.Milestones: The economic crisis deepens, keeping emigration high.

2008.Milestones: Global financial crisis worsens the local economic situation.

2009.Milestones: Austerity measures (Law 7) are implemented, including massive layoffs of public employees.

2010.Milestones: Net emigration again exceeds 30,000; the economic crisis persists.

2011.Milestones: Acceleration of net emigration, reflecting continued economic deterioration.

2012.Milestones: Status plebiscite (majority rejects current status and prefers statehood).

2013.Milestones: Emigration reaches new peaks. Public debt becomes a central issue.

2014.Milestones: The government admits the debt is unpayable. Fiscal reform and local bankruptcy laws are approved (later invalidated).

2015.Milestones: Puerto Rico defaults on part of its public debt.

2016.Milestones: The US Congress passes the PROMESA Act, creating a Fiscal Oversight Board to manage the debt crisis.

2017.Milestones: Hurricanes Irma and Maria cause catastrophic devastation, leading to an unprecedented recent mass exodus. Status plebiscite (low turnout, statehood wins).

2018.Milestones: Post-Maria period. Positive net migration for the first time since 1979, possibly due to returnees, reconstruction workers, or data fluctuations.

2019.Milestones: Massive protests ('Summer of '19') lead to the resignation of Governor Ricardo Rosselló. Positive net migration continues.

2020.Milestones: Sequence of earthquakes affects the southern region. Start of the COVID-19 pandemic impacts global mobility and the economy.

2021.Milestones: Continuation of the pandemic. Debate over post-disaster reconstruction and management of federal funds. (Migration data seems repeated from 2020, verify original source if possible).

2022.Milestones: Hurricane Fiona causes significant damage, especially to the power grid. Notable positive net migration, possible influence of remote work, diaspora return, or economic initiatives.

2023.Milestones: Positive net migration trend continues. Progress in debt restructuring under PROMESA. Debates on energy and economic future.

2024.Milestones: Election year in Puerto Rico and the US. Challenges of reconstruction and economic development persist. (Migration data is likely a projection or preliminary data).
